'Tris' (also known as 'THAM') is an abbreviation of the organic compound known
as tris(hydroxymethyl)aminomethane, with the formula
(HOCH 2) 3CNH 2. Tris is extensively used in
biochemistry and molecular biology. Gomori, G.,
[http://2008.igem.org/wiki/images/8/84/Protein_Buffers.pdf Preparation of
Buffers for Use in Enzyme Studies]. Methods Enzymology., 1, 138-146
(1955). In biochemistry, Tris is widely used as a component of buffer
solutions, such as in TAE and TBE buffer, especially for solutions of nucleic
acids. It is a primary amine and thus undergoes the reactions associated with
typical amines, e.g. condensations with aldehydes.
